Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is seen as an attempt to silence dissenting views that the Australian Government wants to suppress.
The legislation is perceived as infringing on fundamental democratic principles such as freedom of thought and expression.
The submission draws parallels with the American system of democracy, emphasizing the protection of individual rights and limited government powers.
Historical legal cases are cited to argue that the Federal Government's powers are constitutionally limited and should not be expanded without clear justification.
The submission expresses concern over international agreements potentially undermining Australian sovereignty.
The right to express views, even if unpopular, is considered a fundamental democratic right that should only be restricted in times of war or national emergency.
Notable Quotes: The proposed legislation is, in my opinion, wrong in principle, and is an attempt to silence those people who express views that the Australian Government wants to silence.

The right of individuals to hold and express views (that are not intended to incite others to violence), even though those views may be strongly disagreed with by the majority of society, is a basic right in a democracy.
